title: Implement video metadata extraction service

title: Implement jersey number OCR service
description: Extract jersey numbers from player detections using OCR to enable automatic player identification. This service will process bounding boxes from YOLO detections and extract visible jersey numbers.
design:
## Current State
- YOLO detections identify player bounding boxes with high accuracy
- ByteTrack provides persistent tracking IDs across frames
- Court detection filters out audience members
- No jersey number extraction capability yet

## Approach
Use EasyOCR or Tesseract for OCR with preprocessing:
1. Extract cropped player regions from detections
2. Preprocess images (resize, enhance contrast, denoise)
3. Run OCR to extract numbers (focus on numeric characters only)
4. Validate results (basketball jerseys typically 0-99)
5. Store OCR results in new table with confidence scores
6. Aggregate results across multiple frames for same tracking_id

## Integration Points
- Input: PlayerDetection records with bbox coordinates
- Process: Extract frame region, preprocess, OCR
- Output: JerseyNumber table (detection_id, tracking_id, number, confidence)
- Pattern: Similar to court_detector.py - standalone service class

## Performance Considerations
- Run OCR in thread pool (asyncio.to_thread) to avoid blocking
- Only OCR every Nth frame per tracking_id to reduce compute
- Cache results by tracking_id to avoid redundant processing

## Files to Create
- backend/app/ml/jersey_ocr.py - OCR service class
- backend/app/models/jersey_number.py - Database model
- backend/alembic/versions/*_add_jersey_numbers.py - Migration
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Unit test: OCR extracts correct numbers from sample cropped images
- Unit test: Image preprocessing improves OCR accuracy
- Unit test: Validation rejects invalid jersey numbers (>99, negative)
- Unit test: Aggregation combines results from multiple frames

## Manual Testing
- Process video with visible jersey numbers
- Verify OCR correctly identifies at least 70% of visible numbers
- Check that results improve when aggregating across frames
- Confirm no blocking of API during OCR processing

title: Enhance processing status UI with detailed progress
description: Improve job status display to show detailed pipeline stage progress (extraction, detection, tracking, OCR, matching) with frame counts and estimated time remaining.
design:
## Current State
- GameDetail.tsx shows basic progress bars for detection jobs
- Polling every 2 seconds for job status updates
- Progress shows percentage and generic message
- No breakdown by pipeline stage (extraction, detection, tracking, etc.)

## Approach
Enhanced status display with stage-specific progress:
1. Backend: Update job progress messages to include stage info
2. Parse progress message to extract stage and metrics
3. Show multi-stage progress bar (like npm install output)
4. Display metrics: frames processed, detections found, tracking IDs
5. Show estimated time remaining based on current rate
6. Add stage icons (extraction ‚ñ∂Ô∏è, detection üëÅÔ∏è, tracking üéØ, OCR üî¢)

## Implementation Details
- Extend JobResponse.progress to include stages array
- Each stage: {name, current, total, status: 'pending'|'active'|'complete'}
- Update detection_pipeline.py to report structured progress
- Create ProcessingStatusCard.tsx component
- Use existing job polling pattern from GameDetail.tsx

## Files to Modify
- backend/app/services/job_manager.py - Add stages to progress tracking
- backend/app/services/detection_pipeline.py - Report stage-specific progress
- frontend/src/components/ProcessingStatusCard.tsx - New component
- frontend/src/pages/GameDetail.tsx - Use new status card
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Component test: ProcessingStatusCard renders multiple stages
- Component test: Active stage highlighted correctly
- Unit test: Progress message parsing extracts stage info
- API test: Job status includes stages array

## Manual Testing
- Start detection job and watch status updates
- Verify each stage shows progress separately
- Check estimated time remaining updates
- Confirm all stages marked complete when job finishes

title: Improve detection accuracy with fine-tuning and post-processing
description: Enhance player detection accuracy by fine-tuning YOLOv8 on basketball-specific data, implementing temporal smoothing for tracking, and adding post-processing filters to reduce false positives.
design:
## Current State
- Using pre-trained YOLOv8-nano for person detection
- ByteTrack tracking with IOU threshold 0.8
- Court detection filters spatial false positives (bbva-l8b)
- Confidence threshold: 0.5
- No domain-specific fine-tuning yet

## Approach

### 1. Fine-Tuning YOLOv8 on Basketball Data
- Collect/annotate basketball-specific training data:
  * Youth basketball videos with player annotations
  * Variety of angles, lighting conditions, court surfaces
  * 500-1000 annotated frames minimum
- Fine-tune YOLOv8-nano on basketball dataset:
  * Focus on players in basketball uniforms
  * Learn to distinguish players from referees, coaches, audience
  * Improve detection at various distances and angles
- Use transfer learning: freeze backbone, train detection head
- Validate on held-out test set

### 2. Temporal Smoothing for Tracking
- Implement Kalman filter for motion prediction
- Smooth bounding box jitter across frames
- Fill short gaps when player temporarily occluded
- Use velocity estimation to predict next position
- Helps ByteTrack maintain tracks through occlusions

### 3. Post-Processing Filters
- Size filtering: Remove detections too small/large for players
- Aspect ratio filtering: Players typically 1:2 - 1:3 height:width
- Motion filtering: Eliminate static detections (likely not players)
- Confidence smoothing: Average confidence across tracking history
- Non-maximum suppression tuning: Reduce duplicate detections

### 4. Active Learning Pipeline
- Flag low-confidence detections for manual review
- Use reviewed detections as training data
- Iteratively improve model with user corrections
- Track model version and performance metrics

## Implementation Details

### Files to Create
- backend/scripts/train_yolo.py - Fine-tuning script
- backend/app/ml/temporal_smoother.py - Kalman filter implementation
- backend/app/ml/detection_filters.py - Post-processing filters
- backend/app/ml/active_learning.py - Active learning pipeline

### Files to Modify
- backend/app/ml/yolo_detector.py - Load fine-tuned model
- backend/app/ml/byte_tracker.py - Integrate temporal smoothing
- backend/app/services/detection_pipeline.py - Apply post-processing filters

### Configuration
```python
# config.py additions
yolo_model_custom: str = "models/yolo_basketball_finetuned.pt"
use_temporal_smoothing: bool = True
min_detection_size: int = 20  # pixels
max_detection_size: int = 500
min_aspect_ratio: float = 0.3
max_aspect_ratio: float = 0.7
```
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Unit test: Size filter removes too-small and too-large detections
- Unit test: Aspect ratio filter rejects non-player shapes
- Unit test: Temporal smoother reduces bbox jitter
- Integration test: Fine-tuned model improves accuracy on test set

## Manual Testing
- Run detection on validation videos with ground truth
- Measure precision/recall before and after improvements:
  * Target: >90% precision, >85% recall
- Count false positives (audience, referees detected as players)
- Verify tracking stability (fewer ID switches)
- Check processing time impact (should be minimal)

## Performance Goals
- Reduce false positive rate by 50% compared to baseline
- Improve tracking stability (reduce ID switches by 30%)
- Maintain or improve inference speed
- F1 score >0.87 on basketball validation set

title: Implement player-detection matching service
description: Link detected players to known roster by matching jersey numbers from OCR with player records. This service enables automatic player identification in videos.
design:
## Current State
- PlayerDetection table stores bounding boxes with tracking_id but player_id is NULL
- Player and GameRoster tables track which players are in each game
- Jersey OCR service will extract numbers from detections
- No automatic linking between detections and players yet

## Approach
Service to match detections to roster using jersey numbers:
1. Query jersey OCR results for a video/game
2. Group by tracking_id, aggregate confidence scores
3. For each tracking_id, find best jersey number match
4. Look up player_id from GameRoster where jersey matches
5. Update PlayerDetection records to set player_id
6. Handle ambiguity (multiple players same number, low confidence)

## Integration Points
- Input: Video/Game ID, JerseyNumber records, GameRoster
- Process: Match jersey numbers to roster, resolve conflicts
- Output: Update PlayerDetection.player_id
- Pattern: Similar to detection_pipeline.py - service class with database updates

## Matching Logic
- Use majority vote across frames for same tracking_id
- Require minimum confidence threshold (e.g., 0.6)
- Handle edge cases: no OCR results, multiple matches, no roster match
- Log ambiguous cases for manual review

## Files to Create
- backend/app/services/player_matcher.py - Matching service
- backend/app/api/player_matching.py - API endpoints
- API endpoint: POST /videos/{video_id}/match-players
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Unit test: Match single tracking_id to correct player via jersey number
- Unit test: Majority vote selects correct number when OCR varies across frames
- Unit test: Handle no OCR results gracefully (leave player_id NULL)
- Unit test: Handle multiple players with same jersey (flag for manual review)
- Unit test: Only match players in game roster (ignore jersey numbers not in roster)

## Manual Testing
- Run detection + OCR on video with known roster
- Trigger player matching
- Verify PlayerDetection.player_id correctly set for identified players
- Check logs for ambiguous cases requiring manual review

title: Fix tracking stability - ByteTrack integration bugs
design:
Fix critical bugs causing detection/tracking to 'skip in and out inconsistently':

## Root Causes Identified

### Bug 1: Incorrect ByteTrack ID Mapping (CRITICAL)
- Location: backend/app/ml/byte_tracker.py lines 92-124
- Problem: _update_tracking_ids() assumes index alignment between original and tracked detections
- ByteTrack filters and reorders detections, so index-based assignment causes ID swaps
- Fix: Convert FROM sv.Detections (use returned detections as source of truth)

### Bug 2: Filtering BEFORE Tracking (CRITICAL)
- Location: backend/app/services/detection_pipeline.py lines 337-355
- Problem: Court filtering happens before ByteTrack
- If court detection is inconsistent, players get filtered some frames but not others
- ByteTrack never sees these detections, can't maintain tracking continuity
- Fix: Reorder to YOLO ‚Üí ByteTrack ‚Üí Court Filter

### Bug 3: Frame Sampling Breaks Tracker Timing (CRITICAL)
- Location: backend/app/services/detection_pipeline.py line 295
- Problem: sample_interval=3 means tracker sees ~10 FPS on 30 FPS video
- Tracker initialized with frame_rate=metadata.fps (30) - motion predictions are 3x off
- Fix: Pass effective_fps = fps / sample_interval to tracker

### Bug 4: Empty Frames Don't Advance Tracker (HIGH)
- Location: backend/app/ml/byte_tracker.py lines 49-50
- Problem: Early return on empty detections skips tracker update
- ByteTrack needs updates even on empty frames to age lost tracks
- Fix: Always call update_with_detections()

### Bug 5: Court Detection Fallback Floods Tracker (HIGH)
- Location: backend/app/ml/court_detector.py lines 75-77
- Problem: When no court lines detected, returns full-frame mask
- This passes ALL detections (including audience) to tracking
- Fix: Cache last good mask, use conservative central fallback

### Bug 6: Parameters Too Strict (MEDIUM)
- confidence_threshold=0.5 too high (should be 0.35)
- tracking_iou_threshold=0.8 too strict for fast motion (should be 0.6)
- tracking_buffer_seconds=1.0 too short (should be 2.0-3.0s)

## Implementation Plan
1. Fix ByteTrack to convert FROM sv.Detections
2. Reorder pipeline: track before court filtering
3. Fix tracker timing for frame sampling
4. Fix empty frame handling
5. Add court mask caching with conservative fallback
6. Tune parameters
7. Add tracker.reset() at video start
8. Run tests and validate

title: Implement detection API endpoints

title: End-to-end CV pipeline testing
description: Create E2E tests validating the complete computer vision pipeline from video upload through detection, tracking, OCR, and player matching using real test videos.
design:
## Current State
- All CV components implemented: detection, tracking, court detection
- OCR and player matching will be added soon
- No end-to-end integration tests yet
- Backend has pytest infrastructure

## Test Scenarios

### Scenario 1: Full Pipeline with Known Ground Truth
1. Upload test video with known roster and visible jerseys
2. Run detection job and wait for completion
3. Verify detections created with correct frame numbers
4. Verify tracking IDs persist across frames
5. Verify court detection filtered out audience
6. Run OCR and verify jersey numbers extracted
7. Run player matching and verify player_id assigned correctly
8. Compare results to ground truth annotations

### Scenario 2: Error Handling
- Test video with no detectable court (should fall back to full frame)
- Test video with no visible players (should complete with 0 detections)
- Test video with corrupted frames (should skip bad frames)
- Test cancellation of running job

### Scenario 3: Performance Validation
- Test large video (>5 minutes) completes within reasonable time
- Verify API remains responsive during processing
- Check memory usage stays within limits
- Verify database size scales linearly with detections

## Test Data Needed
- Short test videos (10-30 seconds) with ground truth
- Videos with varying quality, angles, lighting
- Ground truth JSON files with expected detections/tracking

## Files to Create
- backend/tests/e2e/test_cv_pipeline.py
- backend/tests/fixtures/videos/*.mp4 - Test videos
- backend/tests/fixtures/ground_truth/*.json - Expected results
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- E2E test: Full pipeline produces expected detections (within tolerance)
- E2E test: Tracking IDs consistent across frames (>90% accuracy)
- E2E test: Court detection filters >50% of audience detections
- E2E test: API responsive during long-running detection job
- E2E test: Job cancellation works correctly

## Manual Testing
- Run pytest backend/tests/e2e/test_cv_pipeline.py
- Verify all E2E tests pass
- Check test execution time <5 minutes for full suite
- Inspect visual output (optional: save annotated frames for review)

title: Write ML pipeline unit tests
description: Create comprehensive unit tests for ML components: YOLO detector, ByteTrack tracker, court detector, and jersey OCR. Ensure each component works correctly in isolation.
design:
## Current State
- ML components implemented: YOLODetector, PlayerTracker, CourtDetector
- No unit tests for ML components yet
- Jersey OCR will be implemented soon
- Backend uses pytest for testing (see backend/tests/)

## Test Coverage Needed

### YOLODetector (backend/app/ml/yolo_detector.py)
- Test model loading (mock model to avoid downloading)
- Test detect_batch with sample frames
- Test confidence filtering
- Test bbox coordinate extraction
- Test person/ball classification

### PlayerTracker (backend/app/ml/byte_tracker.py)
- Test tracking ID assignment across frames
- Test track persistence when detection temporarily lost
- Test IOU matching threshold
- Test track termination after buffer expires
- Test handling empty detection lists

### CourtDetector (backend/app/ml/court_detector.py)
- Test court mask generation from sample frames
- Test line detection (horizontal/vertical classification)
- Test boundary extraction edge cases (no lines, too few lines)
- Test is_point_in_court and is_bbox_in_court
- Test overlap threshold calculations

### Jersey OCR (backend/app/ml/jersey_ocr.py - future)
- Test OCR on sample cropped jersey images
- Test preprocessing pipeline
- Test number validation (0-99 range)
- Test confidence scoring

## Files to Create
- backend/tests/ml/test_yolo_detector.py
- backend/tests/ml/test_byte_tracker.py
- backend/tests/ml/test_court_detector.py
- backend/tests/ml/test_jersey_ocr.py (after OCR implemented)
- backend/tests/fixtures/sample_frames/ - Test images
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
All tests must pass:
- pytest backend/tests/ml/ achieves >80% code coverage
- YOLO tests: 5+ test cases covering main functionality
- ByteTrack tests: 5+ test cases for tracking logic
- CourtDetector tests: 6+ test cases for boundary detection
- Jersey OCR tests: 4+ test cases (after OCR implemented)
- Tests run without downloading models (use mocks/fixtures)

## Manual Testing
- Run full test suite: pytest backend/tests/ml/
- Verify all tests pass
- Check coverage report shows >80% coverage for ML modules

title: Implement detection review UI
description: Create UI for manually reviewing, correcting, and verifying player detections. Users can fix incorrect OCR results, resolve ambiguous matches, and manually assign player_id to detections.
design:
## Current State
- DetectionOverlay.tsx shows bounding boxes on video (bbva-unh)
- No UI for reviewing or correcting detection results
- Player matching may have ambiguous cases requiring manual input
- Detection pipeline complete (bbva-ntd, bbva-43e, bbva-ck1, bbva-l8b)

## Approach
Create review interface with video playback + detection editing:
1. Show video with detection overlay (reuse DetectionOverlay)
2. List detected tracking IDs with OCR results and matched players
3. Allow user to click detection to view details
4. Provide form to edit jersey number, assign player, adjust confidence
5. Show unmatched detections (player_id NULL) separately
6. Filter by confidence, frame range, player

## UI Components Needed
- DetectionReviewPage.tsx - Main page component
- DetectionList.tsx - List of detections grouped by tracking_id
- DetectionEditForm.tsx - Form to edit detection metadata
- Use existing patterns from GameDetail.tsx for layout
- Use existing form patterns from player/game CRUD

## API Integration
- GET /videos/{video_id}/detections (existing - detection.ts)
- PATCH /detections/{detection_id} (new - update player_id, jersey_number)
- GET /videos/{video_id}/unmatched-detections (new - filter NULL player_id)

## Files to Create
- frontend/src/pages/DetectionReview.tsx
- frontend/src/components/DetectionList.tsx
- frontend/src/components/DetectionEditForm.tsx
- backend/app/api/detection.py - Add PATCH endpoint for editing
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Component test: DetectionList renders grouped detections correctly
- Component test: DetectionEditForm submits updates to API
- Component test: Clicking detection in list highlights it in overlay
- API test: PATCH /detections/{id} updates player_id correctly

## Manual Testing
- Open detection review page for video with detections
- Verify all tracking IDs listed with OCR results
- Click unmatched detection, assign player manually
- Verify detection overlay highlights selected detection
- Submit edit and confirm database updated

title: Enable GPU/NPU acceleration for ML inference
description: Optimize ML pipeline performance by enabling GPU acceleration (CUDA for NVIDIA, MPS for Apple Silicon) and exploring Apple Neural Engine for YOLOv8 inference. Improve processing speed for detection and tracking.
design:
## Current State
- Device auto-detection implemented: CUDA ‚Üí MPS ‚Üí CPU fallback (detection_pipeline.py:87-101)
- YOLOv8 supports GPU via PyTorch device parameter
- Currently using asyncio.to_thread() for CPU-intensive operations
- No explicit GPU optimization or benchmarking yet

## Approach

### Phase 1: GPU Acceleration
1. Verify CUDA/MPS support in current environment
2. Enable GPU for YOLO inference (already supported via device parameter)
3. Move ByteTrack to GPU if beneficial (requires profiling)
4. Keep court detection on CPU (OpenCV operations not GPU-intensive)

### Phase 2: Apple Neural Engine (ANE)
1. Convert YOLOv8 model to CoreML format for ANE support
2. Use coremltools to compile model with ANE optimization
3. Fall back to GPU/CPU if ANE unavailable
4. Benchmark ANE vs MPS vs CPU performance

### Phase 3: Batch Optimization
1. Increase batch_size when GPU available (more VRAM = larger batches)
2. Experiment with batch sizes: 8 (CPU), 16 (MPS), 32 (CUDA)
3. Profile memory usage vs speed tradeoffs
4. Add auto-tuning based on available VRAM

## Implementation Details

### Files to Modify
- backend/app/ml/yolo_detector.py - Add CoreML support, batch size tuning
- backend/app/services/detection_pipeline.py - Adjust batch_size based on device
- backend/app/config.py - Add GPU-specific config (batch_size_gpu, use_ane)
- backend/requirements.txt - Add coremltools for ANE support

### Configuration
```python
# config.py additions
yolo_batch_size_cpu: int = 8
yolo_batch_size_gpu: int = 32
enable_apple_neural_engine: bool = True
```

### Benchmarking
- Add performance logging: frames/second, inference time per batch
- Create benchmark script to compare CPU/MPS/CUDA/ANE
- Document optimal settings for each platform
acceptance_criteria:
## Automated Tests
- Unit test: Device detection correctly identifies available hardware
- Unit test: Batch size adjusts based on device type
- Unit test: CoreML model produces same results as PyTorch model (within tolerance)
- Integration test: GPU pipeline produces correct detections

## Manual Testing
- Run detection on same video with CPU, MPS, and CUDA (if available)
- Verify GPU utilization increases during inference (nvidia-smi or Activity Monitor)
- Measure and compare processing speed: frames/second for each device
- Confirm ANE model works on Apple Silicon (if available)
- Verify no accuracy regression with GPU vs CPU

## Performance Goals
- 2-3x speedup on MPS (Apple Silicon) vs CPU
- 4-6x speedup on CUDA (NVIDIA) vs CPU
- ANE comparable or better than MPS (if supported)
